title: Virtual Net Metering Maryland: Community Solar

parts: is virtual net metering considered a community solar system in maryland or can it be connected as a net metered system

content.text: search("virtual net metering community solar Maryland")

content.result:
# 【0†https://energy.maryland.gov/residential/Pages/CommunitySolarGuaranty.aspx#:~:text=Community%20solar%20is%20a%20form%20of%20virtual%20net,subscriber%20organizations%20to%20participate%20in%20the%20pilot%20program.†energy.maryland.gov】
Community solar is a form of virtual net energy metering where the consumer gets energy credit on a local bill for energy produced off-site (but within the same electric utility service area). The Maryland Public Service Commission has authorized certain subscriber organizations to participate in the pilot program.

# 【2†Virtual Net Metering: What Is It? How Does It Work?†www.energysage.com】
Virtual net metering is a solar incentive system that allows community solar subscribers to benefit from net metering. Virtual net metering awards credits for energy produced by solar panels, and those credits translate to discounts on electricity costs. Currently, 41 states and D.C. offer some form of net metering and community solar.
# 【3†Community Solar in Maryland: Net Metering and the Community Solar Pilot ...†www.nexamp.com】
Like net metering, virtual net metering allows Maryland electric customers to receive credits on their utility bill from solar projects that are not located on-site, such as community solar farms. Nexamp community solar subscribers receive virtual net metering credits based on the production of their share of the solar farm.

The Maryland Community Solar Pilot Program commenced in April 2017. Community solar is a form of virtual net energy metering where the consumer gets energy credit on a local bill for energy produced off-site (but within the same electric utility service area).

# 【6†Maryland Energy Administration - Maryland National Guard News†news.maryland.gov】
When you combine community solar with net metering, you have something called virtual net energy metering. Maryland has virtual net energy metering.
# 【7†Community Solar | State, Local, and Tribal Governments | NREL†www.nrel.gov】
Virtual net metering, also referred to as "remote" net metering, allows customers to receive bill credits for generation from an off-site solar energy system. Some form of virtual net metering must exist for community solar to work properly so that multiple customers can offset their electricity loads from a system located elsewhere.

Community solar in Maryland Maryland is implementing a community solar pilot program that will run from 2017-2024. Starting in June 2017, subscriber organizations began the application process to connect their projects to the grid and subsequently request space in the program for each project.

parts:
In Maryland, virtual net metering is considered a mechanism for implementing community solar systems. Community solar in Maryland is described as a form of virtual net energy metering, where consumers receive energy credits on their local utility bills for energy produced off-site but within the same electric utility service area. The Maryland Public Service Commission has authorized specific subscriber organizations to participate in the community solar pilot program, which uses virtual net metering as its operational vehicle【0†source】【1†source】.

Virtual net metering allows electric customers in Maryland to receive credits on their utility bill from solar projects not located on their property, such as community solar farms. This system benefits subscribers by allowing them to receive virtual net metering credits based on the production of their share of the solar farm, similar to traditional net metering but without the requirement for the solar panels to be located on-site【3†source】.

Therefore, virtual net metering in Maryland is directly associated with community solar systems, providing a structured way for residents to participate in and benefit from solar energy production even if they cannot or choose not to install solar panels on their own property.
To dig in deeper, check out these [search results](https://chat.openai.com/backend-api/bing/redirect?query=virtual%20net%20metering%20community%20solar%20Maryland).
what about if it is on the same site with the same ratepayer paying bills with separate accounts?

When virtual net metering is used on the same site with the same ratepayer paying bills across separate accounts, the situation might slightly differ from the typical community solar model. In Maryland, net metering policies generally allow for the physical or virtual aggregation of meters. This means that if there are multiple meters on a single property or for a single entity (ratepayer), these meters can be consolidated virtually for the purposes of net metering. This would allow the electricity generated by a solar system on the property to be credited across multiple accounts held by the same ratepayer.

This setup is often used in scenarios such as campuses, multi-tenant buildings, or businesses with multiple meters. The key advantage is that it enables a single solar installation to benefit multiple accounts, which can be especially beneficial for managing energy costs across different parts of an organization or property owned by the same entity.

However, specific details, such as eligibility criteria, the process for setting up such an arrangement, and any limitations on the size of the solar system relative to the aggregated load of the meters, may be subject to the rules set forth by the Maryland Public Service Commission and the specific policies of the local utility company. Entities interested in this setup should directly consult with their utility company and review the Maryland Public Service Commission's regulations to understand the exact requirements and procedures for aggregating meters under a single solar project within the same site for the same ratepayer.
